awd_titl_txt: Model Inverse Nanocluster Catalysts: The Role of Size, Shape and Composition on the Catalytic Activity of Small Metal Oxide Clusters on Metal Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemical catalysis involves a chemical substance, called a catalyst, which lowers energy costs and creates more selective product distributions by providing another pathway for the chemical reaction of interest.  Catalysts are often employed to generate environmentally friendly fuels, such as hydrogen which burns cleanly to water, and are also used to produce value-added chemicals, like carbon monoxide and methanol which can be made from sustainable crop sources. Because of the importance, catalyst function is a major driving force of research in the chemistry community. Transition metals and transition metal oxides possess many of the desired chemical properties for catalysts that can activate the bonds in CO2, H2O and CH4, which are particularly promising feedstocks for a more sustainable production of fuels and value-added chemicals.  These metals and their oxides can be especially active as small atomic clusters in the 0.00000005 inch or nanometer size range. Nanoclusters exhibit enhanced reactivity due to their unique geometric and electronic characteristics such as under-coordinated surface atoms, modified inter-atomic spacings and large surface to volume ratio.  In this project, Drs. Buratto, Bowers and Metiu produce model catalysts of both metals and metal oxides by deposition of well-defined, atomically-precise nanoclusters from the gas phase onto metal and metal oxide supports. These model systems are then tested for their reactivity in the production of hydrogen and methanol, important as both clean-burning fuels and chemical feedstocks. The research team's unique capability to control nanocluster composition atom-by-atom provides the requisite level of detail to understand the chemistry on the atomic level and provides important insight into the development of new catalytic systems. Drs. Buratto, Bowers and Metiu and graduate students supported by this project are active in outreach to high school students in the Santa Barbara and Ventura Counties to discuss their research and its impact as well as promote science education.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Drs. Buratto, Bowers and Metiu prepare, characterize, and test two new classes of nanoscale catalysts based on the atom-by-atom assembly of small bimetallic and metal oxide clusters having one feature in common; they have very small, isolated, well-defined, catalytically-active sites and enhanced catalytic activity.  The research centers on the preparation of well-defined PdAun and PtSnm clusters supported on single crystal TiO2(110) and well-defined FexOy supported a single crystal Pt(111) in the inverse catalyst geometry. These model systems are prepared by depositing mass-selected clusters from the gas phase onto single crystal surfaces to control catalyst size and composition. Samples are then studied in ultra-high vacuum by x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) to determine composition and structure.  Temperature programmed reaction (TPR) is used to probe the activity to the water gas shift reaction, CO oxidation, and methanol synthesis. Density functional theory (DFT) is used to calculate the structure of the clusters, their XPS spectrum and their chemical activity, and these data are then compared to experiment. The results are used to develop a detailed fundamental understanding of the catalytic chemistry at the atomic level that will in turn help optimize important industrial processes, and improve the performance of the existing catalysts or uncover new ones.  The research groups of Drs. Buratto, Bowers and Metiu are committed to K-12 outreach and the promotion of science in general. They are incorporating their research in heterogeneous catalysis into the University of California Santa Barbara's (UCSB's )5th grade outreach program.  This program brings 5th grade students from elementary schools in the Santa Barbara area to the UCSB campus for hands-on science activities.  The research team is also working with the teachers to develop a lesson in catalysis that is appropriate for the 5th grade curriculum and then incorporate it into the outreach program.  In addition, graduate students supported by this project are active in outreach to high school students in the Santa Barbara and Ventura Counties to discuss their research and its impact, as well as to promote science education.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes for NSF Award CHE-1664995

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Drs. Buratto, Bowers and Metiu have prepared, characterized, and tested several classes of nanoscale catalysts based on the atom-by-atom assembly of small metal oxide clusters supported on single crystal TiO2(110) supports.  Supported metal oxide catalysts were prepared by depositing mass-selected clusters on oxide surfaces to control catalyst size and composition at the atomic level; all samples were prepared and studied in ultra-high vacuum (UHV) by surface science techniques (i.e. AES, XPS, TPD) as well as by scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) before, during and after any chemistry.  Density functional theory (DFT) was used to calculate the structure of the clusters and to predict their chemistry.  Despite wide-spread interest in nanocluster catalysts and their unique reactivity, the fundamental details of the catalytic chemistry remains poorly understood.  We have developed a research paradigm, which allows us to produce model catalysts by deposition of well-defined, atomically-precise nanoclusters from the gas phase onto metal and metal oxide supports. Our research has focused on the reactivity of very small VxOy mass-selected clusters supported on single crystal TiO2(110) surfaces in the oxidative dehydrogenation of methanol.  We utilize scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) to probe the structure of the VxOy nanoclusters on the TiO2(110) surface as well as the structure of adsorbed reactants and products at the atomic level.

Our research has resulted in several important discoveries. First, we have discovered new chemistry in the interaction of methanol and the bare TiO2(110) surface.  We have utilized constant-current STM to directly map the spatial distribution of electronic surface states in a saturated layer of methanol on rutile TiO2(110) as a function of applied bias and adsorbate coverage. The wet electron state is identified by comparing the spatial distribution of local unoccupied states with previously reported DFT calculations.  Using STM imaging, we observed an abrupt change from the delocalized 2D state (bias = +2.17 V) to a localized state (bias = +1.83 V).  The drastic changes in the spatial distribution of methanol LUMO states from a localized 1D state to a delocalized 2D state at 2.05 V above the Fermi level is consistent with the resonant wet electron state previously reported.

We have also investigated the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of methanol into formaldehyde and the deoxygenation of methanol into methane on model rutile TiO2(110) surfaces as a function of substrate reduction.  Our results show that sub-surface Ti interstitials implicated in the reduction of titania are intimately involved in the production of formaldehyde and methane. In addition, TPD/R shows a low temperature methane state below 400 K that we have attributed to edge sites. Room temperature STM investigations of the methanol decorated surface after flashing to 480 K reveal stranded methoxides coordinated to five-coordinated titanium (5c-Ti-OCH3) are the most abundant precursor to ODH and deoxygenation. In addition, we show that the deoxygenation of methanol on a reduced TiO2(110) surface results in oxidation of the surface and the formation of TiOx islands. Our results confirm that Ti interstitials play a critical role in the stabilization and reactivity of 5c-Ti-OCH3 toward both ODH and deoxygenation of methanol.

We have deposited mass-selected VO clusters on the reduced r-TiO2(110) surface and carried out methanol TPD/R and UHV-STM experiments. Our TPD/R results show VO scavenges electrons from the TiO2(110) support and stabilizes the adsorption of both methanol and water at room temperature.  In addition, methanol TPR also reveals a VO-mediated high temperature disproportionation reaction to methanol and formaldehyde.  Room temperature STM experiments following flashes at various temperatures along the methanol desorption pathway confirm a precursor intermediate state consisting of several methoxides bound to VO to form a VO-(OCH3)n complex.  We resolved the structure and formation of the VO-(OCH3)n complexes using STM experiments along with DFT calculations.  Methanol diffuses on the surface until a stable VO-(OCH3)n is formed.  Our results suggest electron-donating point defects such as Ti interstitials and bridging oxygen vacancy are oxidized by the presence of VO, which results in the production of methanol, formaldehyde, and methane at temperatures above 600 K.

Graduate students funded by this grant have had the opportunity to interact continuously with three different research groups, and have acquired hands-on experience in a large number of techniques of surface science, gas-phase chemistry, scanned probe microscopy, and high level theory.  Experimental students have learned how to use theory to get the most out of the data and the theory students have had close interactions with experiments they are trying to understand.  Researchers supported by this grant (including PIs) have also been part of several outreach programs to K-12 schools in the Santa Barbara area.  In addition, researchers have visited high schools in the Santa Barbara and Ventura Counties to discuss their research and its impact as well as to promote science education.

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2023
Modified by: Steven Buratto
